content:
ScrollBar Class

Definition

Represents a control that provides a scroll bar that has a sliding Thumb whose position corresponds to a value.

In this Article

[System.Windows.Localizability(System.Windows.LocalizationCategory.NeverLocalize)]
[System.Windows.TemplatePart(Name="PART_Track", Type=typeof(System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.Track))]
public class ScrollBar : System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.RangeBase

Remarks

The following illustration shows a ScrollBar control.

The ScrollBar control contains a Track control. The Track control consists of a Thumb control and two RepeatButton controls. You can increase and decrease the Value property of the ScrollBar control by pressing the RepeatButton controls or by moving the Thumb. The default range of values for the Value property is from 0 to 1. The Value represents the linear distance of the Thumb between the endpoints of the ScrollBar. You can change the default range of values by setting the Minimum and Maximum properties. The Orientation property determines whether the ScrollBar is displayed horizontally or vertically, and you must define this property for the ScrollBar control to appear.

The Track in a ScrollBar is oriented so that values increase from top to bottom for a vertical ScrollBar or from left to right for a horizontal ScrollBar.

The Track properties in the following table are the binding targets for the corresponding ScrollBar properties when the Track property is not explicitly defined. If you explicitly define the Track property, the binding does not occur.

Track property ScrollBar property
Maximum Maximum
Minimum Minimum
Value Value

You can access the Track control of a ScrollBar control by using the Track property.

To display UIElement content inside a box that has scroll bars, use the ScrollViewer control.

Customizing the ScrollBar Control

To apply the same property settings to multiple ScrollBar controls, use the Style property. You can modify the default ControlTemplate to give the control a unique appearance. For more information about creating a ControlTemplate, see Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate. To see the parts and states that are specific to the ScrollBar, see ScrollBar Styles and Templates.

Dependency properties for this control might be set by the controls default style. If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application. The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running. For more information, see Default WPF Themes.

Note

Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in ScrollBar control's default template and is set by using a . You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate.

Constructors

ScrollBar()

Initializes a new instance of the ScrollBar class.

public ScrollBar ();

Fields

DeferScrollToHorizontalOffsetCommand

The command that notifies the ScrollViewer that the user is dragging the Thumb of the horizontal ScrollBar to the value that is provided in stem.Windows.Input.ExecutedRoutedEventArgs.Parameter*.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand DeferScrollToHorizontalOffsetCommand;

Remarks

When the user drags the thumb of a ScrollBar, the ScrollBar calls CanExecute for the DeferScrollToHorizontalOffsetCommand. If CanExecute returns true, the ScrollBar executes that command. If CanExecute returns false, the ScrollBar executes the ScrollToHorizontalOffsetCommand.

The ScrollViewer uses this command to enable deferred scrolling. When IsDeferredScrollingEnabled is true and a user drags the Thumb of the ScrollBar, the content of the ScrollViewer does not change until the user releases the Thumb. If deferred scrolling is enabled, the ScrollBar executes the DeferScrollToHorizontalOffsetCommand for a horizontal ScrollBar when the user drags the Thumb.

DeferScrollToVerticalOffsetCommand

The command that notifies the ScrollViewer that the user is dragging the Thumb of the vertical ScrollBar to the value that is provided in stem.Windows.Input.ExecutedRoutedEventArgs.Parameter*.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand DeferScrollToVerticalOffsetCommand;

Remarks

When the user drags the thumb of a ScrollBar, the ScrollBar calls CanExecute for the DeferScrollToVerticalOffsetCommand. If CanExecute returns true, the ScrollBar executes that command. If CanExecute returns false, the ScrollBar executes the ScrollToVerticalOffsetCommand.

The ScrollViewer uses this command to enable deferred scrolling. When IsDeferredScrollingEnabled is true and a user drags the Thumb of the ScrollBar, the content of the ScrollViewer does not change until the user releases the Thumb. If deferred scrolling is enabled, the ScrollBar executes the DeferScrollToVerticalOffsetCommand for a vertical ScrollBar when the user drags the Thumb.

LineDownCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a small amount in the vertical direction of increasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand LineDownCommand;

Remarks

This command increases the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the SmallChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the DOWN ARROW key.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.LineDownCommand"/>

LineLeftCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a small amount in the horizontal direction of decreasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand LineLeftCommand;

Remarks

This command decreases the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the SmallChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the left RepeatButton.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.LineLeftCommand"/>

LineRightCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a small amount in the horizontal direction of increasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand LineRightCommand;

Remarks

This command increases the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the SmallChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the right RepeatButton.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.LineRightCommand"/>

LineUpCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a small amount in the vertical direction of decreasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand LineUpCommand;

Remarks

This command reduces the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the SmallChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the UP ARROW key.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.LineUpCommand"/>

OrientationProperty

public static readonly System.Windows.DependencyProperty OrientationProperty;

PageDownCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a large amount in the vertical direction of increasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand PageDownCommand;

Remarks

This command increases the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the LargeChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the PAGE DOWN key.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.PageDownCommand"/>

PageLeftCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a large amount in the horizontal direction of decreasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand PageLeftCommand;

Remarks

This command decreases the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the LargeChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the page button that is to the left of the Thumb. The following illustration shows the page buttons in a ScrollBar.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.PageLeftCommand"/>

PageRightCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a large amount in the horizontal direction of increasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand PageRightCommand;

Remarks

This command increases the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the LargeChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the page button that is to the right of the Thumb. The following illustration shows the page buttons in a ScrollBar.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.PageRightCommand"/>

PageUpCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar by a large amount in the vertical direction of decreasing value of its Track.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand PageUpCommand;

Remarks

This command reduces the Value of the Track in the ScrollBar by the value of the LargeChange property.

This command occurs when the user presses the PAGE UP key.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.PageUpCommand"/>

ScrollEvent

Identifies the Scroll routed event.

public static readonly System.Windows.RoutedEvent ScrollEvent;

ScrollHereCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar to the point of the mouse click that opened the ContextMenu in the ScrollBar.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand ScrollHereCommand;

Remarks

This command occurs when the user selects Scroll Here from the ContextMenu options. The ContextMenu of the ScrollBar appears when the user pauses the mouse pointer over the ScrollBar and presses the right mouse button. This menu provides options for scrolling the ScrollBar.

This command is for a ScrollBar that is part of a ScrollViewer control, and is executed by the ScrollViewer.

XAML Text Usage

< object property=" ScrollBar.ScrollHereCommand"/>

ScrollToBottomCommand

The command that scrolls a ScrollBar to the stem.Windows.Controls.Primitives.RangeBase.Maximum* value.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand ScrollToBottomCommand;

Remarks

For a vertical ScrollBar, this movement occurs when the user presses the CTRL+END keys.

When you implement a ScrollBar as part of a ScrollViewer control, the ScrollViewer executes this command.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.ScrollToBottomCommand"/>

ScrollToEndCommand

The command that scrolls the content to the lower-right corner of a ScrollViewer control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Input.RoutedCommand ScrollToEndCommand;

Remarks

This command is only used with a ScrollViewer control.

XAML Text Usage

< object property="ScrollBar.ScrollToEndCommand"/>

Properties

IsEnabledCore

Gets a value that indicates whether the ScrollBar is enabled.

protected override bool IsEnabledCore { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the ScrollBar is enabled in a ScrollViewer and the size of the content is larger than the display area; otherwise, false. The default is true.

Remarks

This implementation sets IsEnabledCore to true only if the Maximum value of the ScrollBar is greater than the Minimum value and the ScrollBar is enabled.

Orientation

Gets or sets whether the ScrollBar is displayed horizontally or vertically.

public System.Windows.Controls.Orientation Orientation { get; set; }
Value
Orientation

An Orientation enumeration value that defines whether the ScrollBar is displayed horizontally or vertically. The default is Orientation.

Remarks

Dependency Property Information
Identifier field OrientationProperty
Metadata properties set to true None

Track

Gets the Track for a ScrollBar control.

public System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.Track Track { get; }
Value
Track

The Track that is used with a ScrollBar control.

Remarks

A typical style template for a ScrollBar control includes a Track control that is surrounded on either side by two Button controls.

ViewportSize

Gets or sets the amount of the scrollable content that is currently visible.

public double ViewportSize { get; set; }
Value
Double

The amount of the scrollable content that is currently visible. The default is 0.

Remarks

The units that are used for ViewportSize are the same units that are used to describe the length of the content. Some examples include lines of text or pages of text.

The value of the ViewportSize property is used to calculate the size of the Thumb control that is displayed as the sliding value indicator in a ScrollBar control. The Thumb control's size represents the amount of a ScrollViewer control's content that is visible. If 25 percent of a ScrollViewer control's content is visible, the Thumb occupies 25 percent of the track in the ScrollBar.

You can decide which units ViewportSize uses. When you set this property, make sure that the ViewportSize, Minimum, Maximum, and Value properties use the same units.

The following illustration shows how the Thumb size reflects the amount of content that is visible.

Dependency Property Information
Identifier field ViewportSizeProperty
Metadata properties set to true None

Methods

OnApplyTemplate()

Creates the visual tree for the ScrollBar.

public override void OnApplyTemplate ();

Remarks

This implementation also sets the Track property to the Track that is defined in the ScrollBar template.

OnContextMenuClosing(ContextMenuEventArgs)

Provides class handling for the ContextMenuClosing event that occurs when the ContextMenu for a ScrollBar closes.

protected override void OnContextMenuClosing (System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuEventArgs e);
e
ContextMenuEventArgs

The event data.

Remarks

The ContextMenu of a ScrollBar provides options for changing the Value of the ScrollBar.

OnContextMenuOpening(ContextMenuEventArgs)

Provides class handling for the ContextMenuOpening event that occurs when the ContextMenu for a ScrollBar opens.

protected override void OnContextMenuOpening (System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuEventArgs e);
e
ContextMenuEventArgs

The event data.

Remarks

The ContextMenu of a ScrollBar provides options for changing the Value of the ScrollBar.

OnCreateAutomationPeer()

Creates an AutomationPeer for this ScrollBar control.

protected override System.Windows.Automation.Peers.AutomationPeer OnCreateAutomationPeer ();
Returns
AutomationPeer

A ScrollBarAutomationPeer for the ScrollBar control.

OnPreviewMouseLeftButtonDown(MouseButtonEventArgs)

Provides class handling for the PreviewMouseLeftButtonDown event.

protected override void OnPreviewMouseLeftButtonDown (System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs e);
e
MouseButtonEventArgs

The event data.

Remarks

This implementation changes the Value of the ScrollBar to the location of the PreviewMouseLeftButtonDown event that occurs while the user presses the SHIFT key. The event is handled by setting Handled in the event data e to true.

OnPreviewMouseRightButtonUp(MouseButtonEventArgs)

Provides class handling for the PreviewMouseRightButtonUp event.

protected override void OnPreviewMouseRightButtonUp (System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs e);
e
MouseButtonEventArgs

The event data.

Remarks

This implementation saves the position of the mouse click so that the ScrollBar can scroll to that position in response to a ScrollHereCommand.

Events

Scroll

Occurs one or more times as content scrolls in a ScrollBar when the user moves the stem.Windows.Controls.Primitives.Track.Thumb* by using the mouse.

public event System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.ScrollEventHandler Scroll;

Remarks

This event typically occurs multiple times when the user changes the Value of the ScrollBar by dragging the Thumb. There is no limit to the number of times this event is raised as the Thumb position is dragged.

This event is not raised when the Value of the ScrollBar control is changed in code.

Routed Event Information
Identifier field ScrollEvent
Routing strategy Bubbling
Delegate ScrollEventHandler
